reviewText: The Seventh entry in the Bond franchise, Diamonds Are Forever follows up On Her Majesty's Secret Service with Sean Connery being pushed back into the role as Agent 007.  This would be the last official James Bond film to star Sean Connery, and would be the sixth time the film featured Connery as the title character.  It is somewhat a bittersweet ending to Connery's legacy since the film's campy elements seem like they would be more at home in Roger Moore's series of Bond films and not the semi-serious realm of the Connery film.  I wouldn't have suspected the director of the classic Goldfinger to come back with such a campy entry in the series.The film is very fun to watch and probably has some of Connery's best comic one-liners ("It seems you've caught me with more than my hands up") and is amusing to watch, but it suffers in so many other aspects.  It really does usher in the 70s Bond before Moore even enters the picture and whether that's good or bad is up to the viewer to decide.  If you are a fan of the Roger Moore Bond films you will probably like Diamonds Are Forever, but if you're expecting a more serious, Connery Bond film on the level of Thunderball or Goldfinger you'll most certainly be disappointed.  Even though Connery stars this really is essentially the first "Moore" Bond film.That being said I found this movie very entertaining, if not up to the standards of Connery's other five films.  Diamonds Are Forever may be a dopey film in premise, but it's an incredibly amusing film that you should just go along with.If you don't want campy Bond just avoid this movie, but if you're like me and enjoy most of the Bond films you will probably enjoy the lunacy that is Diamonds Are Forever.

reviewText: Sean Connery's last romp as 007 (until the non-EON producedNever Say Never Again [Blu-ray]) takes a decidedly more campy approach compared to previous Bond films--while there was always an element of camp writer Tom Mankiewicz and director Guy Hamilton also include some wry moments hinting at an aging 007 (he gets his butt kicked by Bambi and Thumper two guards late in the film). On the whole "Diamonds are Forever" though fits well within the Bond tradition with more humor certainly thanFrom Russia with Love [Blu-ray] but a slightly less camp value when compared toLive and Let Die [Blu-ray].The film looks good--it's not specatcular--and does benefit from the HD treatment. Blacks aren't crushed throughout and in some scenes detail and depth are especially goodl Colors are a bit washed out but that was typical of the newer films being produced by Kodak and Technicolor at the time and, as a result, it looks pretty close to what it probably looked like in 1971.The mono audio is presented lossless and sounds quite nice.The special features--most of which are ported over from the DVD--are great. We get a combined commentary track with producers-actors-writer Mankiewicz-director Hamilton discussing the making of the film, changes that occurred to the script during production including a changed ending due to budget constraints.We also get deleted scenes. I'm surprised these have survived all these years and these include a cameo with Sammy Davis Jr., a scene that explains WHY Plenty O'Toole ended up in at the bottom of the swimming pool, an extended scene as well as footage of test explosions, cut footage from the attack on the oil rig which included scuba diving agents. There's also a vintage 1971 interview with the BBC where Connery admits he only read three of the Bond novels (one of which "Live and Let Die" is one he doesn't appear in) When asked why he didn't read the others, he is diplomatic--my guess is that he just didn't feel it necessary.There are additional cool special features included which, as I have time to go through them, I will update this review.007 finds himself surround by diamonds when he tries to find out the connection between a diamond smuggling ring, SPECTRE and the elusive richest man in the world Willard Whyte (Jimmy Dean)who no one has seen in 5 years. In the process Bond puts together involvement of Blofeld (Charles Grey)and a conspiracy that would have fit in well (and provided much of the basis for theAustin Powers Collection (International Man of Mystery / The Spy Who Shagged Me / Goldmember) [Blu-ray] movies which clearly "Diamonds are Forever" provided most of the template for (at least the first film).There are some stunning set pieces including an assault on an oil rig, a nasty fight in a small, confined elevator and car chase throughout Las Vegas that make this a Bond film STILL worth viewing. I have sentimental ties to the film as this was the first film Bond film my dad took me to see. Your milesage may vary depending on how well you can stomach the camp quality. Of special note is Bruce Glover (Crispin Glover's dad) an underrated character actor who also appeared inChinatown [Blu-ray]andWalking Tall: The Trilogy [Blu-ray]. Glover is a marvelous actor who manages to breathe life into even the most marginal character and he has a lot to work with here as one of the bad guys that constantly dogs Bond and tries to kill him on several occasions.Bottom line: This looks quite good in its HD premiere on disc. Could it look better? Probably but the effort is much appreciated that Lowry went to as they spiffed this up quite a bit. The special features are great. A minor quibble--I hate these eco-friendly Blu-ray packages as they have holes in them where the BD could be damaged.Please note some of these titles (especially any that are exclusive to Walmart at this time) have no movie money for "Skyfall".
summary: Campy but still enjoyable Bond thriller with Connery as smooth as ever-Blu-ray review

reviewText: This is the seventh Bond movie, and the seventh with Connery in the lead role. I guess, by the time this came around, the whole crew had a hard time taking it quite as seriously as before. As much as I like Bond, Connery, and the whole series of movies, I think this was a step away from the right direction.It got off to a strong start, with an international hopscotch of Bond on the trail of Blofeld, the boss bad guy. It goes down hill fairly fast, with henchman #1 drowning more or less voluntarily in a pool of mud and Blofeld passing away in a similarly cooperative manner. And that's before we get to the Bouncing Bond Babes of the introduction graphics. After that, gratuitous one-liners take the place of witty banter, despite a few good action sequences. The real disappointment, though, is Kidd and Wint. I haven't read Fleming's original yet, but I can't believe that he recruited a pair of grinning fops for high-profile assassinations and comic relief. This movie is so old that it was OK back then to make fun of mated males in a wink-wink-nudge-nudge manner, so that lovely couple winked and nudged their charming way right down to the last scene.But I'm just kvetching. "Diamonds" has good action, for its time. It has the appeal of the Bond, the sophisticated bon vivant and baddest badboy on the block, as moviegoers were prepared to see it back then. And it features a lovely bikini stuffed to overflowing with Jill St. John, of the time when the Bond Girl wasn't supposed to be threatening or even very competent.
